newsitem.title: USA: CSCE coffee called to open 3.00-4.00 cents lower.
newsitem.headline: CSCE coffee called to open 3.00-4.00 cents lower.

text.p: CSCE coffee futures were called to open 3.00 to 4.00 cents lower Friday in a technical correction to this week's blistering rally, traders said.
"It's way overbought," said one trader. "It is due for a correction, but I'm not sure who is going to sell it."
New York arabica futures shot up for the third straight day Thursday, with July coffee soaring to a new 20-year high, on a nearly uninterrupted broad-based buying frenzy.

July arabicas jumped to a new lifetime high of 318.00 cents per lb, the highest price since 1977, before closing at 314.80 cents, up 19.25 cents. Second-position September jumped 17.10 cents higher, to 273.80 cents, while the back months rose 6.00 to 14.25.

The July/September spread, a barometer of near-term supplies, widened to 41.00 cents from 38.85 cents at the close on Wednesday. September/December bulged to 45.00 cents from 42.15 cents on Wednesday.

On fundamental side, U.K. trade house ED&F Man said Friday world consumer coffee stocks stood at 10 million bags in April, up from 8.80 million in March and 1.1 million bags higher than in April 1996.
While growth has been concentrated in European ports, Man said April/May coffee report that U.S. stocks increased by 309,000 bags in the last two months to stand at 1.85 million bags.
After Thursday's close, CSCE reported certified coffee stocks dipped 454 60-kg bags, to 49,258 bags as of May 28. There was no coffee pending grading, the exchange said.

In London, robusta futures pulled back early Friday, on profit-taking after Thursday's explosive run-up to 20-month highs. LIFFE July dropped $59 at the midday break, to $2,541, while September fell $53, to $2,577.
